title: 114_s2860
content:
The Climate Change Adapt America Bond Act of 2016 includes sections on the establishment of a Climate Change Advisory Commission, the creation of an Adapt America Fund, and the issuance of Climate Change Bonds. The Act also provides definitions for key terms used within the legislation. The Climate Change Adapt America Bond Act of 2016 establishes a Climate Change Advisory Commission, an Adapt America Fund, and issues Climate Change Bonds. Key definitions include the Commission, Fund, and Secretary. The Climate Change Advisory Commission is established with 11 members appointed from various sectors and institutions. The Climate Change Advisory Commission consists of 11 members appointed from different sectors. Each member serves for the duration of the Commission, with appointments made within 90 days of the Act's enactment. Vacancies do not impact the Commission's powers and are filled as per the original appointment method. The Commission must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed, with meetings called by the Chairperson. A majority of members form a quorum for meetings. The Climate Change Advisory Commission consists of 11 members appointed from different sectors. A majority of members constitute a quorum for meetings, with the Commission selecting a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson from among its members. The Climate Change Advisory Commission consists of 11 members appointed from different sectors, with a majority forming a quorum for meetings. The Commission selects a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson from among its members. SEC. 102 outlines the duties of the Commission. The Commission establishes recommendations, frameworks, and guidelines for a Federal investment program funded by revenue from Climate Change Bonds. This program aims to improve and adapt energy, transportation, water, and general infrastructure impacted by climate variability, integrating the best available science and data to enhance infrastructure resiliency. Additionally, the Commission identifies cost-effective investments and projects with multiple benefits. The Commission identifies cost-effective investments and projects with multiple benefits to commerce, human health, and ecosystems. SEC. 103. COMMISSION PERSONNEL MATTERS. Members of the Commission are compensated based on their status as federal employees or non-federal employees. Non-federal employees receive daily pay equivalent to level IV of the Executive Schedule, while federal employees serve without additional compensation. Travel expenses, including per diem, are provided for Commission members. The Chairperson of the Commission may appoint necessary personnel without following civil service laws and set their compensation. The Chairperson of the Commission can appoint personnel without following civil service laws and set their compensation, with a maximum rate not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. The Commission will use funds from the Fund for administrative expenses and will terminate after completing its duties. The Adapt America Fund is established. The "Adapt America Fund" is established within the Department of Commerce. The Secretary is responsible for implementing the Fund in accordance with the Act. A program will be carried out to provide funds for climate change adaptation projects to eligible entities, including Federal agencies, States, local governments, and utility districts. An eligible entity, such as a government, utility district, tribal government, transit agency, nonprofit organization, or special purpose district, can apply for funds for climate change adaptation projects. The Secretary will select projects based on criteria set by the Commission, and non-Federal funding is required to receive funds. To receive funds for climate change adaptation projects, eligible entities must provide at least 25% of the project funds. The funds deposited in the Fund must be used for new projects only, and Federal laws and regulations still apply to projects receiving funds under this Act. SEC. 202 of the Act requires contractors and subcontractors on projects funded by the Fund to pay laborers and mechanics prevailing wages. The Secretary of Labor determines these rates. SEC. 203 states that the Secretary will use available funds for the program. TITLE III--CLIMATE CHANGE BONDS

SEC. 301. CLIMATE CHANGE BONDS. The Secretary of the Treasury will issue "Climate Change Bonds" within 6 months of the Act's enactment, with proceeds going to the Fund. These bonds will be issued as savings bonds and backed by the full faith and credit of the United States. They are exempt from local taxation. The Secretary will issue Climate Change Bonds annually with a face amount of $200,000,000. The funds for these bonds will come from available sources not already designated for the purposes of this section. The Secretary will promote the purchase of Climate Change Bonds through various means, with a promotion budget not exceeding $10,000,000 per fiscal year from 2017 to 2021. Additionally, the Secretary will seek donated advertising for the bonds and there is an authorization of $10,000,000 for each fiscal year during the same period.
